G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Under G.L. c. 208, § 28, a custody judgment may be modified upon a showing of changed circumstances and where the proposed modification would serve the best interests of the child.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: Filed Pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and G.L. c. 209C, § 20

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7\u00a7 10\u201320.proposition: The Middlesex Probate and Family Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, G.L. c. 209C, §§ 10–20, and G.L. c. 215, § 6.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: The Middlesex Probate and Family Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, G.L. c. 209C, §§ 10–20, and G.L. c. 215, § 6.

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The Massachusetts courts have consistently held that when the original basis for a custody arrangement has significantly changed, a modification is warranted.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion is not a modification case and does not apply or discuss the "substantial change in circumstances" standard governing modification of an existing custody judgment. In fact, the court explicitly declines to apply that modification standard and instead treats the case as an initial custody determination under the best interests framework. Thus, it neither states nor reaffirms any rule that a significant change in the original basis for custody warrants modification, and so it does not support the claimed proposition.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: "We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a). ... It is clear from the record that the case in the Probate Court was tried under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), not G. L. c. 209C, § 20..."

Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).proposition: The Massachusetts courts have consistently held that when the original basis for a custody arrangement has significantly changed, a modification is warranted.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).support_reasoning: This case involves modification of alimony and child support, not custody. The court reiterates the standard that a party seeking modification must show a material change in circumstances, and ultimately finds no such change; it does not discuss or apply any rule about modifying custody arrangements. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority that Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a significant change in the original basis for a custody arrangement warrants modification.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment. Robbins v. Robbins, 343 Mass. 247, 249 (1961). Hinds v. Hinds, 329 Mass. 190, 191-192 (1952). In this case, the judge held that Chester did not prove the requisite change of circumstances.”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: The “material and substantial change” standard ensures that modification serves the child’s welfare and stability.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns the standard for allowing removal of children from the Commonwealth where parents share joint physical custody, focusing on the statutory "upon cause shown" requirement, interpreted as a pure best-interests test. It does not discuss or apply a separate "material and substantial change" standard, nor does it link such a standard to ensuring welfare and stability; that language appears only in a block-quoted ALI provision and is not adopted as Massachusetts law. Accordingly, the case does not provide authority for the claimed proposition about the role of a material and substantial change standard.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt:
The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002), as adopted and promulgated by the American Law Institute, state in pertinent part:
“(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances . . . only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgment of divorce] …
“(4) When a relocation constituting changed circumstances . . . renders it impractical to maintain the same proportion of custodial responsibility to each parent, the court should modify the parenting plan in accordance with the child’s best interests …”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: When a parent’s conduct potentially endangers the child, it constitutes a sufficient change in circumstances.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion is a direct-appeal custody and property division case; it does not involve a post‑judgment modification or any analysis of what constitutes a “material change in circumstances.” The court discusses best interests, parental conflict, and some problematic conduct (e.g., hygiene during visitation) only as factors in the initial custody/visitation determination, not as a threshold change-in-circumstances standard. Thus, the case does not establish that a parent’s potentially endangering conduct constitutes a sufficient change in circumstances.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “We do not think it would serve any useful purpose to recount portions of the evidence from which the judge could reasonably have determined that incidents inconsistent with the best interests of the children (e.g., substandard personal hygiene) occurred during certain extended periods when the husband was exercising his visitation rights under the temporary custody order.”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: When a parent’s conduct potentially endangers the child, it constitutes a sufficient change in circumstances.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The case focuses on whether a request to relocate and a court‑ordered temporary change in custody constitute the kind of material and substantial change in circumstances required to modify custody. The Appeals Court holds that these factors, standing alone and absent evidence of harm, do not justify a custody change and finds no post‑divorce change warranting modification. The opinion does not discuss parental conduct that potentially endangers the child as a sufficient change in circumstances, so it does not support the cited proposition.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “A judgment modifying custody must be based on findings grounded in the evidence that, since the date of the prior custody order, there has been a change in circumstances ‘of sufficient magnitude to satisfy the governing principle… whether the transfer of custody will be conducive to the welfare of the [child].’ … There is nothing in the findings or the record before us to indicate that anything occurred after the divorce that so altered the circumstances of the parties as to warrant a change in custodial arrangements….”

Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232 (1981).proposition: Courts prioritize the best interests of the child in all custody determinations.
Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232 (1981).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly frames custody/visitation disputes in terms of promoting the child’s best interests and recognizes that parental liberties may be limited to serve that goal. While the case ultimately reverses a visitation restriction for lack of proof of harm, it reaffirms that the ‘dominating goal’ in these matters is the child’s best interests, consistent with the proposition that courts prioritize those interests in custody determinations.
Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232 (1981).relevant_excerpt: “But the ‘best interests’ of the child are to be promoted, and when the parents are at odds, the attainment of that purpose may involve some limitation of the liberties of one or other of the parents. … If the dominating goal of the enterprise is to serve a child’s best interests, as the cases asseverate (see Vilakazi v. Maxie, supra at 409; cf. G. L. c. 208, § 31 [as to awards of custody])…”

Zatsky v. Zatsky, 36 Mass. App. Ct. 7 (1.raw_text: Zatsky v. Zatsky, 36 Mass. App. Ct. 7 (1994)
Zatsky v. Zatsky, 36 Mass. App. Ct. 7 (1.proposition: Massachusetts law authorizes modification to impose supervision or restrictions when warranted by evidence of harm or instability.
Zatsky v. Zatsky, 36 Mass. App. Ct. 7 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with delay, appeal procedure, and general modification of divorce judgments based on material change in circumstances under G.L. c. 208, § 37, but it does not discuss modifying custody or parenting arrangements to add supervision or restrictions based on evidence of harm or instability. The references to modification are purely about financial/support aspects and arrearages. There is no holding or reasoning about imposing supervised or restricted arrangements as a form of modification, so it does not support the specific proposition claimed.
Zatsky v. Zatsky, 36 Mass. App. Ct. 7 (1.relevant_excerpt: “All the same, a complaint to modify under § 37 is an available remedy if a material change in circumstances has already occurred since the time the judgment was entered, i.e., a Probate Court has power to entertain such a complaint… We affirm the judgment of December 1, 1989… That clears the decks for a complaint under G. L. c. 208, § 37, for modification of the judgment on grounds of a material change in circumstances.”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: The Court has a continuing duty under Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996), to ensure the child’s best interests are protected as circumstances evolve.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on the need for explicit findings about domestic violence and its effect on the child when making a custody determination, and remands for additional findings. It does not articulate a general, ongoing or ‘continuing duty’ of the court to monitor and adjust custody as circumstances evolve over time; the only forward-looking reference is a practical note that, because time has passed, the judge may reassess the child’s preference and the interim arrangement on remand. That is not framed as a broad, continuing legal duty applicable beyond the remand proceedings in this case.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: "Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication. ... Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking. ... As almost three years have gone by since the Probate Court issued its judgment and Vaughn is now almost fourteen years of age, it may be appropriate for the judge to interview the child again as to his preference and for the judge to evaluate the success of the stipulated custody arrangement the parties have been living under in the interim."

Adoption of Paula, 420 Mass. 716 (1995).proposition: The evidence described herein reflects a pattern consistent with diminished parental fitness or supervision by Defendant, a factor directly relevant under Adoption of Paula, 420 Mass. 716 (1995).
Adoption of Paula, 420 Mass. 716 (1995).support_reasoning: The case is fundamentally about assessing parental fitness in the context of adoption and termination of parental rights, and it treats a sustained pattern of neglect, abuse, substance abuse, chaotic home conditions, and failure to protect as clear and convincing evidence of current parental unfitness. While the opinion does not use the phrase “diminished parental fitness or supervision,” its analysis explicitly links a long-term pattern of harmful parenting conduct and inadequate supervision to a finding of unfitness that is directly relevant to adoption decisions. Thus it provides authority that such patterns are legally significant to parental fitness determinations.
Adoption of Paula, 420 Mass. 716 (1995).relevant_excerpt: “While it was apparent that the mother cared about her children and could, to some extent, identify their individual needs, the judge concluded that she remained unable to acknowledge the damage caused to her children by the ‘chaotic, frightening and harmful environment’ which had existed in the marital home, and that she did not understand the ‘causes and manifestations of child abuse’ and would, therefore, be unable to protect her children from renewed abuse… Taken together, [the findings] constituted clear and convincing evidence of the mother’s current unfitness to care for the seven children….”

Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: Continued unsupervised overnight visitation is inconsistent with the child’s safety and welfare as articulated in Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion applies a general "best interests of the child" standard to decide which parent should have primary physical custody in the context of a relocation dispute; it does not announce any categorical rule that continued *unsupervised overnight visitation* is inconsistent with a child’s safety and welfare. The court actually affirms an order that grants the noncustodial parent substantial parenting time, including overnights and extended summer and holiday visits, while finding primary physical custody should be with Hunter. Thus, the case does not support the specific proposition that continued unsupervised overnight visitation is per se inconsistent with the child’s safety and welfare.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: Moreover, the judge stated that, should Rose decide to move back to Massachusetts, the parties must work in good faith to adjust their parenting plan to meet Jill’s best interests. … The judge’s custody order gave Rose frequent contact with Jill, including parenting time one weekend per month in Massachusetts, five weeks in the summer, school vacations, holidays, Web camera sessions three evenings per week, and telephone calls once per week.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7\u00a7 10, 20.proposition: (Citations: G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, §§ 10, 20; G.L. c. 215, § 6; Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232 (1981); Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981); Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001); Zatsky v. Zatsky, 36 Mass. App. Ct. 7 (1994); Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); Adoption of Paula, 420 Mass. 716 (1995); Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).
